messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last two hundred years, new tools helped children live longer.  
Health also.  
This made the number of people grow fast.  
Big families had more children.  
Those children grew up and had their own children.  
In the 1960s, birth control became easy to get.  
Then the world’s usual number of babies for each woman fell.  
It went from six babies to about two babies.
Feedback received: Grade 2/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.5833 is catastrophically below the required 0.75 threshold. The text has lost the core message of the original.

- Primary Failure (Meaning): The original text establishes a clear cause-and-effect relationship: 'improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young'. Your version, 'new tools helped children live longer. Health also,' breaks this critical link into two disconnected statements, fundamentally altering the logic of the text.

- Secondary Failure (Fidelity): The BERTScore of 0.889 is below the minimum requirement of 0.90. This is a direct result of replacing precise terminology with vague approximations. The phrase 'global average number' was replaced with 'world’s usual number', which is not an equivalent concept. Key lexical items like 'improvements' and 'availability' were completely lost.

- Structural Defect: The sentence 'Health also.' is a fragment. While simple, it is grammatically incomplete and demonstrates a failure to construct a proper A2 sentence.

Suggestion: Re-write the first two sentences to restore the cause-and-effect relationship. Example: 'Because of better tools and health, more children lived for a long time.' Suggestion: Restore the meaning of 'global average'. Use 'the average number for the whole world'. Suggestion: Do not use sentence fragments.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.5801 is catastrophically below the required 0.75 threshold. The text has been simplified to the point of losing its core message.

- Primary Failure: The critical concept of 'babies per woman' has been completely omitted. Your text states 'the average number for the whole world fell... from six babies to about two babies'. This is meaningless. The average number of what? This omission destroys the central fact of the original text.
- Secondary Failure: The BERTScore of 0.8886 is below the minimum requirement of 0.90. This indicates a failure to retain key lexical information.
- The text, while linguistically simple (A2), fails its primary purpose of conveying the original information accurately.

Suggestion: You must restore the core meaning. Rephrase the final sentences to include the concept of 'per woman'. Example: 'The average number of babies for each woman fell. It went from six babies to about two babies for each woman.'

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last two centuries, better tools and health saved many children.  
This made the world population grow fast.  
Big families had many children.  
Those children grew up and had children.  
In the 1960s, birth control became easy to get.  
The world average number of babies per woman fell.  
It fell from about six babies per woman.  
It fell to about two babies per woman.
Feedback received: Grade 2/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.5719 is catastrophically below the required 0.75 threshold. The text has failed its primary purpose of conveying the original message.

- Primary Deviation (MeaningBERT): The score of 0.5719 indicates a severe loss of meaning. The original text establishes a direct cause and effect: 'improvements... meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth'. Your version splits this into two disconnected ideas: 'saved many children' and 'This made the world population grow fast'. This separation breaks the logical link and fails to preserve the core message.

- Secondary Deviation (BERTScore): The BERTScore of 0.8958 is below the minimum requirement of 0.90. This reflects a loss of key lexical items. Phrases like 'improvements in technology' and 'wider availability of contraception' were oversimplified, losing necessary detail.

- Structural Flaw: The text is excessively fragmented. The sentences 'It fell from about six babies per woman. It fell to about two babies per woman.' are redundant and demonstrate poor construction. This is not effective A2 writing; it is simply broken English.

- Suggestion: Restore the cause-and-effect relationship immediately. Combine the final two sentences into a single, coherent A2 statement. Example: 'The average number of babies per woman fell from about six to two.'

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last two centuries, new technology and health helped children survive.  
This made the world population grow fast.  
Big families had many children.  
Those children grew up and had children.  
In the 1960s birth control became widely available.  
The average number of babies per woman fell from six to two.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.68 is significantly below the required 0.75 threshold. The core message was not adequately preserved.

- Meaning Loss: The original text states that 'fewer children died young', which directly caused population growth. Your version, 'helped children survive', is too general and weakens this critical cause-and-effect relationship.
- Factual Omission: You removed the word 'global' when describing the average number of babies. This is a loss of specific information from the original text.
- Vocabulary Violation (B1): The word 'survive' is not A2 level. It must be replaced.
- Vocabulary Violation (B2): The word 'widely' is not A2 level. It must be replaced.

Suggestion: Rephrase the first sentence to explicitly state that fewer children died. Replace 'survive' with an A2 phrase like 'live longer'. Replace 'widely available' with a simpler concept like 'easy to get'. Restore the word 'global'.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last two centuries, fewer children died young.  
This made the world population grow fast.  
Big families had many children.  
Those children grew up.  
They had children of their own.  
In the 1960s, birth control became easy to get.  
The global average number of babies per woman fell.  
It fell from six to two.
Feedback received: Grade 1/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.5802 is a catastrophic deviation from the required 0.75 minimum. The text has failed to preserve the core message of the original source.

- Primary Failure: The original text establishes a clear cause-and-effect relationship: 'improvements in technology and health' led to fewer child deaths. Your version completely omits this critical piece of information, stating only the effect. This is an unacceptable loss of meaning.
- Secondary Failure (Fidelity): The BERTScore of 0.8989 is below the 0.90 threshold. This is a direct result of omitting key phrases like 'improvements in technology and health'.
- Vocabulary Violation: The word 'global' is B1-level vocabulary. It was used without simplification, violating the strict A2 word list requirement.

Suggestion: You must restore the lost meaning. Re-introduce the cause for the population change. Example: 'Technology and health got better. So, fewer children died young.' Replace the word 'global' with an A2-level phrase. Example: 'in the world'.

- Primary Failure: You completely omitted the time frame 'In the last two centuries'. This is a critical factual detail from the original text. Its removal is an unacceptable loss of information.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last two centuries, technology and health got better.  
Fewer children died young, so the population grew fast.  
Big families had many children.  
Those children grew up6.  
They had children.  
In the 1960s, birth control became more available.  
The average number of children per woman fell from six to two.
Feedback received: Grade 2/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Factual Inaccuracy. The sentence 'Those children grew up6.' contains a numerical error. The number '6' is incorrect and corrupts the meaning of the sentence. Adherence to factual integrity is the absolute first priority; this error constitutes an instant failure.

In addition to the primary failure, the text also fails on a secondary metric.

- Fidelity Failure: The BERTScore of 0.897 is below the required 0.90 threshold. This indicates a loss of key lexical detail. The concept 'survived into adulthood' was oversimplified to 'grew up', contributing to this score drop.
- Structural Deficiency: The text is excessively fragmented. The sequence 'Big families had many children. Those children grew up. They had children.' breaks a single, connected idea from the original text into three choppy, disconnected statements.

Suggestion: Remove the numerical error immediately. Combine the fragmented sentences to restore the original's logical flow using a simple connector. Rephrase to improve fidelity. Example: 'These big families had many children, and those children grew up to have their own families.'

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last two centuries, technology and health got better.  
Fewer children died young, so the population grew fast.  
These big families had many children.  
Those children grew up and had their own families.  
In the 1960s, birth control became more available.  
The average number of children per woman fell from six to two.
Feedback received: Grade 10/10 - PASS

metadata.feedback_text:
PASS: The text successfully meets all A2 criteria.

- Factual Integrity: All facts, numbers, and concepts from the original text are accurately represented. The timeline, cause of population growth, and specific numbers for birth rates are correct.
- Meaning Preservation: The MeaningBERT score of 0.85 and BERTScore of 0.91 are well above the required thresholds, confirming that the core message has been maintained with high fidelity.
- CEFR Compliance: The text correctly classifies as A2. The vocabulary and sentence structure are perfectly aligned with this level.
- Vocabulary Audit: The vocabulary is strictly limited to A1 and A2 words. Terms like 'technology', 'population', and 'birth control' are appropriate for the A2 level.
- Structural Analysis: The use of short, simple sentences connected by basic conjunctions like 'so' and 'and' is an exemplary execution of A2 structural requirements. The text is clear and easy to follow.
